abstract: It was a heartbreaking yet galvanizing preview of what the human body can endure — physically, emotionally and spiritually.
snippet: It was a heartbreaking yet galvanizing preview of what the human body can endure — physically, emotionally and spiritually.
lead_paragraph: My iPhone’s Face ID function stopped recognizing me the day after my miscarriage, a hilariously modern alert that I’d never be the same person again.

headline.main: My Miscarriage Cured My Fear of Childbirth

abstract: Black women have intimate and sometimes fraught relationships with our hair. Today, my hair is helping me work out the most important relationship I’ll ever have: the one I have with myself.
snippet: Black women have intimate and sometimes fraught relationships with our hair. Today, my hair is helping me work out the most important relationship I’ll ever have: the one I have with myself.
lead_paragraph: I should have been at summer camp. Instead, I was sitting in a hair salon with my mom, grandmother and a hairdresser named James Brown (the perfect name for a hairdresser who tapped into the soul of his clients).

headline.main: Combing My Hair and Finding Myself

abstract: My grandma Trudy used to tell us that she had “healing hands.” I soon discovered that I did, too.
snippet: My grandma Trudy used to tell us that she had “healing hands.” I soon discovered that I did, too.
lead_paragraph: You could say I was primed to be a witch from an early age.

headline.main: Here’s What Being a Witch Really Means

abstract: As the daughter of protective Somali parents, I was sheltered and, eventually, indifferent to learning to drive. But in one exhilarating moment behind the wheel, I began my journey into adulthood.
snippet: As the daughter of protective Somali parents, I was sheltered and, eventually, indifferent to learning to drive. But in one exhilarating moment behind the wheel, I began my journey into adulthood.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll start driving when Saudi Arabian women are allowed to!” I would declare to my mom as a teenager, as if I were one of those celebrities who used to promise that they wouldn’t marry until gay people could. I was always half-kidding, but jokes have a way of dressing up inertia in a glossy armor.

headline.main: License to Not Drive
headline.print_headline: Driven to Get a License? Not Exactly

abstract: As a teenager, crushes were my religion. I obsessed over boys from a born-again Christian youth group like a fanatic, and I found peace in this faith.
snippet: As a teenager, crushes were my religion. I obsessed over boys from a born-again Christian youth group like a fanatic, and I found peace in this faith.
lead_paragraph: When I was 14, I joined a born-again Christian youth group, despite having a Jewish last name and a lackluster-at-best interest in the teachings of Jesus Christ. I did it for the only reason that I did anything at that age: I had a crush on a boy.

headline.main: A Christian Youth Group Turned Me Jewish

abstract: The writer spent her mid-20s anticipating a psychotic break that never came. Soon to be a mother herself, she reflects on fear, family history and the future.
snippet: The writer spent her mid-20s anticipating a psychotic break that never came. Soon to be a mother herself, she reflects on fear, family history and the future.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of my 25th birthday, I looked at the wall calendar from my spot in bed, horizontal and snug beneath the covers. And I waited. I knew what turning 25 meant in my family.

headline.main: Schizophrenia Runs in My Family. What Does That Mean for Me and My Baby?

abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.
lead_paragraph: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.

headline.main: The Immigrant Dream Realized in One Evening
headline.kicker: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: THE MEMORIES
headline.print_headline: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: THE MEMORIES; The Immigrant Dream Realized in One Evening

abstract: How did it come to this? My stars were not aligned.
snippet: How did it come to this? My stars were not aligned.
lead_paragraph: I’m sitting with my hands clasped in a prayer. My eyes flutter between open and close. A scarf draped over my head refuses to stay put. A fire crackles gleefully in front of me.

headline.main: The True Story of My Marriage to a Pot
headline.print_headline: She Married a Clay Pot. The Breakup Was Inevitable.

abstract: It was in Colorado — surprise, surprise — where you can look at the stars and the trees won’t judge you for being 27.
snippet: It was in Colorado — surprise, surprise — where you can look at the stars and the trees won’t judge you for being 27.
lead_paragraph: I’m not exciting. I’m sleepy by 10 p.m. and resent any plans that keep me out of my apartment, far from my pajamas; I’m not a huge fan of flying, so I tend to not go on too many trips; and spicy foods aren’t for me.

headline.main: The First Time I Got High
headline.print_headline: The First Time I Got High

abstract: “Fake it till you make it” didn’t work out so well in my case, and I was fired after three long months.
snippet: “Fake it till you make it” didn’t work out so well in my case, and I was fired after three long months.
lead_paragraph: “This is not an easy place to get hired,” said a fellow analyst at the company, an elite, private-sector global intelligence organization.

headline.main: My Very Brief Career as the World’s Worst Detective

abstract: The fighting in Yugoslavia forced my family to immigrate to Canada, where I found solace on the court.
snippet: The fighting in Yugoslavia forced my family to immigrate to Canada, where I found solace on the court.
lead_paragraph: I am wearing my best tennis whites and nervously picking at the strings on my wooden Wilson racket. The new grip my coach helped me wrap around the handle the night before has that fresh, just-out-of-the-package smell. I am about to compete in my first tournament.

headline.main: When War Turned My Country Into Chaos, Tennis Gave Me a Home

abstract: “You are going to have to work 10 times harder.” This is how my father prepared me for being black in America.
snippet: “You are going to have to work 10 times harder.” This is how my father prepared me for being black in America.
lead_paragraph: We sat at a dirty table covered in used napkins and crumbs, leftovers from the guests who dined before us. My father took a clean napkin, swept the trash away and sat silently. He didn’t often accompany me on trips to the mall — in fact, I can’t recall a time when he had before, and he wouldn’t after.

headline.main: The Other Talk

abstract: Here’s how I came to hate summer — and you can, too!
snippet: Here’s how I came to hate summer — and you can, too!
lead_paragraph: Here we are, at the end of another summer — at least symbolically, if not officially — and I couldn’t be happier.

headline.main: Some Like It Hot. Not Me.

abstract: As I struggle with chronic pain, cozy for me is less hygge and more my ex-boyfriend’s mother, nurses with juice and weird, sandy doughnuts.
snippet: As I struggle with chronic pain, cozy for me is less hygge and more my ex-boyfriend’s mother, nurses with juice and weird, sandy doughnuts.
lead_paragraph: Cozy is my religion. There are few things in life I take as seriously as the cultivation and preservation of comfort. My mother says it’s because I’m a Taurus (“they love luxury!”). My father calls it being a bed creature. My friend Jemima spits, “You very rarely do anything that could possibly make you uncomfortable,” as I cancel yet another evening plan.

headline.main: Call Me Cozy

abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.    Maybe Mom and Dad missed their prom because they were too cool for formals and lavender cummerbunds, but not these teen-agers. Prom is hip again, they say.
lead_paragraph: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.

headline.main: T-Shirts Forsaken In Favot Of Top Hats
headline.kicker: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: TUXEDOS
headline.print_headline: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: TUXEDOS; T-Shirts Forsaken In Favot Of Top Hats

abstract: They were the topic of many conversations about my heritage — and the bane of my existence. But when I decided to embrace my brows, they became my secret weapon.
snippet: They were the topic of many conversations about my heritage — and the bane of my existence. But when I decided to embrace my brows, they became my secret weapon.
lead_paragraph: For the past 10 years, almost every new interaction I’ve had with a person — romantic, platonic, professional — has followed the same script.

headline.main: Taking Back My Eyebrows

abstract: It required two things that don’t come naturally to me: acting helpless and asking for help.
snippet: It required two things that don’t come naturally to me: acting helpless and asking for help.
lead_paragraph: Nick was trying to cut a piece of squid with a butter knife in his right hand as he rocked our baby to sleep with his left while seated in a self-consciously hip tapas joint during a recent family vacation in Spain.

headline.main: How I Trained My Husband to Be a Dad
headline.print_headline: How I Trained My Husband to Be a Dad

abstract: When my husband died, I was soothed by the hand-designed furniture he left behind. Eventually, some of it had to go.
snippet: When my husband died, I was soothed by the hand-designed furniture he left behind. Eventually, some of it had to go.
lead_paragraph: In my family, the old saying “The shoemaker’s daughter goes barefoot” had special meaning. My mother and father manufactured high-fashion women’s shoes sold in Bloomingdale’s and Saks, while I opted to wear construction boots or clogs on most days.

headline.main: Letting Go of the Sentimental but Not Very Comfortable Couch

abstract: It’s called the yips, and it’s a sudden inability to play. I had to find my way out of it.
snippet: It’s called the yips, and it’s a sudden inability to play. I had to find my way out of it.
lead_paragraph: I quit playing baseball when I was 11 years old. That was the cutoff for girls; after that point, we had to switch to softball, and I wasn’t having it.

headline.main: Baseball Was My Life. Then I Stopped Being Able to Throw the Ball.

abstract: Also in attendance will be my ex-girlfriend, a Mariah Carey impersonator and five butterflies, which I will release. Then I will emerge from a giant sac, 40 pounds lighter.
snippet: Also in attendance will be my ex-girlfriend, a Mariah Carey impersonator and five butterflies, which I will release. Then I will emerge from a giant sac, 40 pounds lighter.
lead_paragraph: I never much cared for butterflies as a child, because to me they symbolized death. Their very existence represented the end of a caterpillar’s life, and I have always preferred beginnings to endings, no matter how beautiful.

headline.main: It’s Called a Butterfly Party and You’re Invited

abstract: After the wedding, he introduced me as his wife. I don’t know why this startled me so much, but each time he said it I shrunk inside.
snippet: After the wedding, he introduced me as his wife. I don’t know why this startled me so much, but each time he said it I shrunk inside.
lead_paragraph: My mother, in an effort to keep me humble and rooted, likes to remind me of embarrassing facts from my childhood. Her favorite one lately: I marched up and down the hallway belting out “Here Comes the Bride” with a sheer beige curtain over my head as a veil. If anyone asked me what I wanted to be when I grew up, my 5-year-old voice proudly said, “a bride.”

headline.main: How I Came to Hate the Word ‘Wife’

abstract: As a child, I had dreamed of taking my husband’s last name. Then I got engaged to Eddie.
snippet: As a child, I had dreamed of taking my husband’s last name. Then I got engaged to Eddie.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Obermueller thought I would take his last name once I became his wife.

headline.main: A Married Name That Looks Nothing Like Us

abstract: I was 27, new to New York and suffering from terrible anxiety. Then, on doctor’s orders, I slapped on some headphones.
snippet: I was 27, new to New York and suffering from terrible anxiety. Then, on doctor’s orders, I slapped on some headphones.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t listen to music until I was 27 years old. And even then, it wasn’t entirely by choice. It was suggested to me by one doctor and several Reddit users.

headline.main: How I Discovered This Thing Called Music

abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.
lead_paragraph: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.

headline.main: A Shopping Spree to Be The (Only) Lady in Red
headline.kicker: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: THE GOWN
headline.print_headline: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: THE GOWN; A Shopping Spree to Be The (Only) Lady in Red

abstract: I did not see the body positivity movement coming, not at all.
snippet: I did not see the body positivity movement coming, not at all.
lead_paragraph: I was a chubby little kid. I loved toast, butter, cookies, orange juice, ice cream and hamburgers, and I didn’t like moving around that much. I wasn’t a snacker, or a grazer.

headline.main: The Diet Industrial Complex Got Me, and It Will Never Let Me Go

abstract: Would going gray require me to listen to folk music, host potlucks and wear caftans? Or could it be another way of being a woman in the world?
snippet: Would going gray require me to listen to folk music, host potlucks and wear caftans? Or could it be another way of being a woman in the world?
lead_paragraph: As I sat in the colorist’s chair in a high-end salon, I could not help but admire how young I looked. My gray roots had just been obliterated with a $300 Chernobyl of Deep Chocolate Mocha and Buttery Caramel lowlights.

headline.main: How I Quit the Bottle (the Hair Dye Bottle)
headline.print_headline: Celebrating Life With a Silver Crown

abstract: My feminist mother taught me to speak up. Now, as a trans man, I am trying to make space for women to be heard.
snippet: My feminist mother taught me to speak up. Now, as a trans man, I am trying to make space for women to be heard.
lead_paragraph: A few months after I began injecting testosterone, I discovered that one of the startling new privileges of my male body was that I could silence an entire room just by opening my mouth.

headline.main: My Voice Got Deeper. Suddenly, People Listened.

abstract: Who doesn’t love making signs and getting angry with other people? Rage is a stronger social lubricant than alcohol, and it’s free!
snippet: Who doesn’t love making signs and getting angry with other people? Rage is a stronger social lubricant than alcohol, and it’s free!
lead_paragraph: I have always loved a good protest.

headline.main: I Don’t Go to Parties. I Go to Protests.

abstract: I’ve worked nonstop since I was a teenager. Now, at 50, I’m hitting pause. It feels scary but necessary.
snippet: I’ve worked nonstop since I was a teenager. Now, at 50, I’m hitting pause. It feels scary but necessary.
lead_paragraph: “You’re so brave,” my friend said when I told her I was going to take some time off after leaving my job as an executive of a hotel chain.

headline.main: What Am I if Not Employed?

abstract: When my father died, I wanted desperately to know the timing of this thing. But grief doesn’t have a timeline.
snippet: When my father died, I wanted desperately to know the timing of this thing. But grief doesn’t have a timeline.
lead_paragraph: I got a text message from my father.

headline.main: There Are No Five Stages of Grief

abstract: As a gay kid growing up in the South, I worried that the gesture would telegraph my sexuality. The reality was I just wanted to shrink.
snippet: As a gay kid growing up in the South, I worried that the gesture would telegraph my sexuality. The reality was I just wanted to shrink.
lead_paragraph: For as long as I can remember, I’ve crossed my legs. This is hardly a declaration, and, since I’m not a celebrity or dating one, neither breaking news nor worthy of trending status. It’s just something that comes to mind when I read stories about gender, sexuality, toxic masculinity and the power and politics of the body in America.

headline.main: I Cross My Legs. Does That Make Me Less of a Man?

abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.
lead_paragraph: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.

headline.main: Tuxedo and Gown Parade Gets Approval and a Lift
headline.kicker: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: THE GATHERING
headline.print_headline: FROM THE SUBURBS TO THE INNER CITY, PROMS ENDURE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE: THE GATHERING; Tuxedo and Gown Parade Gets Approval and a Lift

abstract: Becoming a grandmother was joyful and thrilling, but it was tempered by a stinging knowledge: that my grandchild’s life would unspool into a string of birthdays I will not live to see.
snippet: Becoming a grandmother was joyful and thrilling, but it was tempered by a stinging knowledge: that my grandchild’s life would unspool into a string of birthdays I will not live to see.
lead_paragraph: I was in the delivery room when my first grandchild was born. It was a gift from my daughter to be invited in at all — I know I can be overbearing sometimes — and I cherished the invitation like a rare and precious gem.

headline.main: The Ecstasy and the Agony of Being a Grandmother

abstract: I know Karens are hard. As a member of Gen X, I grew up surrounded by them.
snippet: I know Karens are hard. As a member of Gen X, I grew up surrounded by them.
lead_paragraph: While everyone is complaining about boomers, Gen Z doesn’t want you to forget to complain about Generation X, the other generation that’s significantly older than them that also sucks. This sucking is embodied by the name Karen, the young people have noticed — middle-aged white moms who are always asking for the manager and calling the police on perfectly fine pool parties and wondering why kids are so obsessed with their identities.

headline.main: My So-Karen Life

abstract: I wasn’t one of those alcoholics who paired up with caregivers. I couldn’t think of anything worse than codependency — I was more about co-debauchery.
snippet: I wasn’t one of those alcoholics who paired up with caregivers. I couldn’t think of anything worse than codependency — I was more about co-debauchery.
lead_paragraph: A mutual friend at work had set us up, and from the moment he walked into that dark hipster bar, late and apologetic, I knew he was The One.

headline.main: Drunks, in Love

abstract: We want to read your stories.
snippet: We want to read your stories.
lead_paragraph: Hello, we have an update!

headline.main: How to Submit a ‘Rites of Passage’ Essay

abstract: I have arrived at a life phase in which my dad is crushing on a silver-haired grandmother, and I’m giddily becoming his girlfriend’s girlfriend.
snippet: I have arrived at a life phase in which my dad is crushing on a silver-haired grandmother, and I’m giddily becoming his girlfriend’s girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: His one-finger-peck technique meant he was perpetually bent over his screen, loafing at the breakfast table amid drained coffee cups or lingering in the car long after the rest of us had gotten out.

headline.main: Meeting My 84-Year-Old Father’s New Girlfriend

abstract: My patient had a simple, devastating request. To honor it meant grappling with how a therapist responds to her clients.
snippet: My patient had a simple, devastating request. To honor it meant grappling with how a therapist responds to her clients.
lead_paragraph: I was mainlining pretzels in my office kitchen as I waited for Julie to arrive. Whenever she was late, I would think the worst. Should I check on her between sessions or let her call if she needed me because I knew she had trouble asking for help? Should therapists’ boundaries be different — looser — with terminally ill patients?

headline.main: ‘Will You Stay With Me Until I Die?’

abstract: I had a lot of questions about my career in tech, but of one thing I was certain: I did not want a child. Then I met a girl who needed me as much as I needed her.
snippet: I had a lot of questions about my career in tech, but of one thing I was certain: I did not want a child. Then I met a girl who needed me as much as I needed her.
lead_paragraph: When I was 34 and single, a social services caseworker asked me if I wanted to adopt a 14-year-old girl. Wanted. The word wilted in my chest. How had my life meandered to a place where someone thought I wanted to be a mother? How could I explain to the caseworker that becoming a mother was never part of my plan?

headline.main: My Almost Motherhood

abstract: At least my “this is your brain on drugs” generation understood fear. Now, narcotics are the new boxed wine.
snippet: At least my “this is your brain on drugs” generation understood fear. Now, narcotics are the new boxed wine.
lead_paragraph: The assignment was to write a four-page research paper on any biology topic. My son, Sebastian, is a high school freshman, and it was his first real chance to shine. I expected him to pick something like photosynthesis. He went with psychedelic drugs instead.

headline.main: How to Talk to Your Kids About Drugs When Everyone Is Doing Them

abstract: My immigrant father worked hard to provide for me and my mother. But at some point I had to decide who I was and what I wanted, and I wasn’t sure it was a seven-diamond engagement ring.
snippet: My immigrant father worked hard to provide for me and my mother. But at some point I had to decide who I was and what I wanted, and I wasn’t sure it was a seven-diamond engagement ring.
lead_paragraph: I peered into the glossy box trembling in Sam’s hands. Inside sat an oval-cut diamond engagement ring. Hand-engraved leaves and milgrain edges detailed the rose gold band, while a baguette and two smaller diamonds hugged both sides of the center stone.

headline.main: Vladimir the Jeweler

abstract: I wanted to uncover ancient shards of my childhood gender and piece them back into the whole.
snippet: I wanted to uncover ancient shards of my childhood gender and piece them back into the whole.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, I spent Christmas with my family in North Carolina with a mission: to digitize a dozen or so of my favorite childhood photos.

headline.main: Excavating My Childhood Photos — and Myself

abstract: I had no history of cancer in my family. At 41, getting a mammogram was just a thing to check off my to-do list.
snippet: I had no history of cancer in my family. At 41, getting a mammogram was just a thing to check off my to-do list.
lead_paragraph: When you find out you have breast cancer, you might be pulling ramen from water with a pasta fork. Your son might be watching “SpongeBob,” so you might hear that dull drone of Patrick Star the starfish in your mind as you fall.

headline.main: Surprise, You Have Early Breast Cancer

abstract: When I found out I was pregnant at age 24, there was no decision to make. But even if it felt inconsequential at the time, I don’t take for granted that I had a choice.
snippet: When I found out I was pregnant at age 24, there was no decision to make. But even if it felt inconsequential at the time, I don’t take for granted that I had a choice.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t notice my skipped period. I had switched birth control pills, and my menstrual cycle had always been a little irregular. It wasn’t like a movie, either. When I started vomiting, it didn’t even dawn on me that I was pregnant. I thought it was some symptom of cancer.

headline.main: The Abortion I Almost Forgot

abstract: You know that scene in “Lady Bird” when Saoirse Ronan throws herself out of a moving vehicle to avoid talking to her mother for another second? That was me, at 14, in the car with my father.
snippet: You know that scene in “Lady Bird” when Saoirse Ronan throws herself out of a moving vehicle to avoid talking to her mother for another second? That was me, at 14, in the car with my father.
lead_paragraph: Before his fingers had reached the volume knob to turn off Steely Dan, I already knew: My bookish and tightly wound father was about to tell me something I did not want to hear.

headline.main: Talking Sex With Dad (in the Ford Taurus)
